title: 106_hr5447
content: The Act titled "Social Security Administration Preparedness Act of 2000" addresses administrative expenses of the Social Security Administration. The Act "Social Security Administration Preparedness Act of 2000" amends the authorization of administrative expenses for fiscal years 2001 and 2002 from the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. It also includes provisions for reports. The Act "Social Security Administration Preparedness Act of 2000" redesignates subparagraphs and requires program performance reports to include documentation of fund usage and performance levels to achieve the mission of the Social Security Administration. The Administration is committed to achieving modern, customer-responsive service and protecting program integrity. The Commissioner must submit plans to relevant committees. The Inspector General of the Social Security Administration prepares an annual performance plan and report on program performance. The Inspector General must submit an annual report on program performance to specific committees, detailing the use of appropriated funds and plans for the following fiscal year to effectively carry out the office's mission. The Comptroller General of the United States must assess the Social Security Administration's performance goals and submit a report to the President and Congress within 90 days after the annual budget submission. The report includes recommendations for improving performance. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to establish and maintain an advanced technology system to meet future program demands. A technical panel of IT experts will assist in this process. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit a comprehensive information technology investment plan biennially to congressional committees, detailing progress and performance goals in implementing IT requirements. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to submit an IT investment plan biennially to congressional committees, outlining performance goals, project costs, benefits, risks, and returns. The plan must include a process for measuring goal achievement. The Comptroller General of the United States will assess the plan within 90 days and provide recommendations to relevant committees. Amendments to the Act include changes to subparagraph (G). In subparagraph (H), amend by changing "subparagraph (B)(i)" to "subparagraph (F)(i)". SEC. 3. LIMITATION OF SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to specify limits on Social Security administrative expenses in appropriations bills. For fiscal year 2001, the new budget authority is set at $7.5 billion with $7.4 billion in outlays. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to specify limits on Social Security administrative expenses in appropriations bills. For fiscal year 2002, the new budget authority is $8.45 billion with $8.35 billion in outlays. Administrative expenses include expenses for information technology acquisition and the Office of Inspector General. Budget committees will adjust budget allocations accordingly. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to specify limits on Social Security administrative expenses in appropriations bills. The definition of administrative expenses of the Social Security Administration is clarified in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The Social Security Act is amended to exclude administrative expenses from budget calculations, effective October 1, 2002. This change applies to the budget of the United States Government, congressional budget, and the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
